definition[0]: the process of watching something or someone carefully for a period of time
example[0]: He spent two nights under close observation in hospital.
example[1]: His orders were to keep the men under observation.
example[2]: Art classes help develop children’s powers of observation.
example[3]: Careful observation suggests that this is not the case.
example[4]: Detailed observations were carried out on the behaviour of the students.
example[5]: From their direct observations, children absorb a model of marriage.
example[6]: Bloomfield’s approach to linguistics was based on observation of the language.
definition[1]: something that you notice when watching something or someone
example[7]: Some interesting observations emerged from this research.
definition[2]: a spoken or written remark about something you have noticed
example[8]: Darwin’s observations on the habits of certain birds
example[9]: Paz makes some observations about the role of the critic.
definition[3]: the act of obeying a law etc
example[10]: The police said that the house had been under observation.
example[11]: The doctor ordered that the patient be kept under observation.
example[12]: In the past, people used their own powers of observation to forecast the weather.
example[13]: A lot of useful knowledge is gained by careful observation of the world around you.
example[14]: Even casual observation makes this theory improbable.
example[15]: Piaget developed his theories based on direct observation of children.
example[16]: I knew cigarettes were addictive from personal observation.
example[17]: Scientific observation led to the discovery of vaccines.
example[18]: Classroom observation is only part of what school inspectors do.
example[19]: The peak of the mountain was a natural location for an observation post.
example[20]: The army built an observation tower on the top of the building.
example[21]: The hospital released him after a period of observation.
